title: 106_hr1845
content: The Act may be cited as the "Aviation Bilateral Accountability Act of 1999" and pertains to civil aviation agreements. Section 40105 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include a provision for Congressional review of civil aviation agreements. The agreement will only enter into force for the United States if the Secretary transmits the final text to Congress and no disapproval resolution is introduced within a 20-day period of continuous session. The agreement must be transmitted to Congress by the Secretary, and if no disapproval resolution is enacted within a 90-day period of continuous session, or if a veto is not overridden within a specified timeframe, the agreement will enter into force for the United States. The President can veto a message from Congress, and the continuity of a session is only broken by an adjournment sine die. The number of days when either House is not in session due to an adjournment of more than 3 days is excluded in the calculation of the specified period. This subsection is enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House for the procedure to be followed. The disapproval resolution process in Congress allows for joint resolutions to disapprove civil aviation agreements between the United States and other countries. This process supersedes other rules in the House and can be changed at any time by either House. The disapproval resolution process in Congress allows for joint resolutions to disapprove civil aviation agreements between the United States and other countries. The resolutions are referred to specific committees in the House and Senate for review within a specified timeframe. The disapproval resolution process in Congress allows for joint resolutions to disapprove civil aviation agreements between the United States and other countries. If a committee does not report the resolution within 45 days of its introduction, the committee is automatically discharged from further consideration. No amendments are allowed to a disapproval resolution in either the House or Senate, and prior action by the other house follows specific procedures. The House procedure for floor consideration of a disapproval resolution is highly privileged and not debatable. Amendments to the motion are not allowed, and reconsideration of the vote is also not permitted. The House of Representatives limits debate on a disapproval resolution to 5 hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing. Motion to limit debate further is not allowed. It is also not permitted to move to recommit or reconsider the vote on a disapproval resolution. Motions to postpone or proceed with other business are decided without debate. The House of Representatives limits debate on a disapproval resolution to 5 hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing. Appeals from the Chair's decisions on the application of House rules are decided without debate. Consideration of a disapproval resolution follows House rules unless specified otherwise. In the Senate, a motion to proceed to consider a disapproval resolution is allowed. In the Senate, a disapproval resolution reported by the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation is privileged and not debatable. Debate is limited to 10 hours, divided between the majority and minority leaders. Appeals are decided without debate. In the Senate, debate on a disapproval resolution is limited to 1 hour for any debatable motion or appeal. Time is divided between the mover, resolution manager, and minority leader. Additional time can be allotted by the leaders during consideration of motions or appeals. In the Senate, debate on a disapproval resolution is limited to 1 hour for any debatable motion or appeal. A motion to further limit debate is not debatable, and a motion to recommit a disapproval resolution is not in order.
